Award.AwardTitle: Woods Hole Oceanographic Institution/ Ocean Class AGORS Oceanographic Instrumentation
Award.AbstractNarration:
This proposal requests $447,279 to build a portable Jumbo Piston Coring System for the Ocean Class vessels of the UNOLS Fleet.
Sediment coring supports high impact science in a diverse array of disciplines in the geosciences.
Access to reliable coring systems is essential for addressing a number of critical questions of both scientific and societal importance, including almost all of the scientific priorities outlined in the Decadal Survey of Ocean Sciences. Despite the continued importance of sediment coring technologies, there is widespread community concern that there has been an erosion of sediment coring capability available to the U.S. research community. Based on the responses to a community survey and discussions during a workshop convened at the National Science Foundation in May 2015, the scientific community expressed a high priority for the development of a robust and portable Jumbo Piston Coring system that is capable of deployment on all Global and Ocean Class vessels and capable of collecting cores of up to 20 m length over the full range of ocean depths (?Science Driven Assessment of Needs for marine Sediment Coring 2015- 2025,? Report of Workshop at NSF, 28-29 May 2015).

Broader Impacts
The principal impact of the present proposal is under Merit Review Criterion 2 of the Proposal Guidelines (NSF 13-589). It provides infrastructure support for scientists to use the vessel and its shared-use instrumentation in support of their NSF-funded oceanographic research projects (which individually undergo separate review by the relevant research program of NSF). The acquisition, maintenance and operation of shared-use instrumentation allows NSF-funded researchers from any US university or lab access to working, calibrated instruments for their research, reducing the cost of that research, and expanding the base of potential researchers

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project was funden to enable the construction of a new hybrid Jumbo piston coring [JPC] system capable of recovering sea floor sediment samples up to 25 meters long.  The portable system was designed for rapid mobilization on the Ocean Class AGORS:  Neil Armstrong operated by the Woods Hole Oceanographic Institution, and the Sally Ride of the Scripps Institute of Oceanography. The system will provide the US research community with a global capability of collecting long, ‘high quality’ piston cores. The system was adapted from the proven WHOI developed JPC that has been installed on more than a dozen research vessels and icebreakers. 

 

The new JPC was modified to enable deployment with synthetic fiber rope.  , this project included funds for a 10,000 meter length of a high modulus fiber strength member to replace the traditional 9/16” wire rope currently standard aboard UNOLS vessels in the fleet.  The advantages of employing a modern UHMWPE rope [Ultra High Molecular Weight Polyethylene] are well known and include no weight in water, and negligible elongation at full ocean depths which minimizes core disturbance. Adapting the JPC for use with a synthetics require changes in the triggering mechanism to an acoustic release, but otherwise the proposed core system  mimics one that has recovered thousands of piston cores from the world oceans.

 Due to unfortunate circumstances concerning strength members employed, two system were lost on sea trials.  A report of the losses was submitted to the NSF after the expedition.

The accompaning pictures illustrate system components.
